author: XularusXIII

text:
And about the X series.

* X's OST kicks ass. Storm Eagle, Boomer Kuwanger and Spark Mandrill are awesome, and the rest is very good and powerful too.
* I don't remember X2 and X3 very well.
* X4 OST is inferior to the SNES games'.
* X5 and X6 are clearly worse than the SNES ones, though the boss theme and a couple of other tracks are interesting.
* X7 and X8 are horrible.

You can also find some good tracks in other MM games, like Network Transmission.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
Thanks for your reply. My opinion would differ from that one now, though...

* 1 has a good OST.
* 2 and 3 both have outstanding OST's, probably 3 being better than 2.
* 4 is the best OST from the series.
* 5 and 6 have a couple of good tracks, but the overall quality is inferior.
* 7 is not up to par with the NES games.
* 8 is BAD.
* Megaman & Bass is somewhat unknown to me.
* 9 and 10 from Wii are both excellent, especially Magma Burning, Flash in the Dark and Nitro Man's theme.
author: Diego Vizia

author: Daniel Davidov

text: I'm ordinarily a fan of SupraDarky's choices and I've found a lot of great music through him, but this is sub-par. I could see someone liking it because it resembles the actual game's music, which may be better on the DS than on Youtube (And remembering that tune through hearing this one), but to someone who is just listening to this objectively, it is not very good. The chords are alright, but the melody is unimpressive, very much a generic anime-styled-game theme.

author: Stephen Pamphile

text:
@axlar1 Yeah, Megaman  8 OST sucked pretty bad.

Megaman 9 soundtrack is truly excellent, one of the best. And MegaMan 10 OST, while not as good as MM9's, is still very good and it has the best song of all the entire saga: Nitro Man.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
@axlar1 I don't think it's the best, but it's true that MegaMan 3 has a good OST. Anyway, I still keep my opinion that only two tracks are outstanding: Snake Man and Spark Man. Spark Man is one of the best of the series though in my opinion.

Not everyone likes the same things. I like a certain style of composition (in minor, with a defined melody, a good bass line, use of dominant and secondary dominants, etc.). Maybe you like another thing, and that's OK too.
author: Diego Vizia

author: Sayeth Di Puppeth

text: Mega Man ZX takes place 200 years after the end of the Zero series (Zero 4), which is ultimately about 500 years or so after the original Mega Man games.  Even though the Zero games were incredibly dark and depressing, the world of the ZX series is considerably brighter and more of a futuristic utopia, with plenty of natural environments as well.  Much of the game's backstory follows directly from the Zero series, so if you're a fan of the Zero series, you can't NOT play this game--it's amazing.
author: speyeker

text: It's a great game, but it's very short.  Some of the backstory comes right from the Zero series, but if you haven't played a Mega Man game before, you should still be able to get into the swing of things.  If you find the game too hard, you might want to practice with some other 2D platformers beforehand (ideally other Mega Man games as they all play very similar, but I think any platformer will do as long as it's not brutally hard).

author: Erghest

text:
Yup, just listen to this track...

* From 00:00 to 00:15, it lacks melody completely. There's just a synth bass and soft string in the background
* From 00:15 to 00:30 there's a simple melody with about 5 or 6 different notes.
* Then the song starts and you can tell the melody, but the chord succession lacks emotion and the feeling is just not right for a videogame. It's something like VI, V, I, (IV) --- VI, VII, I... which in this tonality translates to G, F#m, Bm, E --- G, A, Bm.
author: Diego Vizia

text:
"lacking defined melody and chords"

WTF!? *head asplodes*
author: speyeker

text:
Well, if you like music with electronic percussion and soft instruments lacking defined melody and chords, then Zero and ZX music will be your choice.

If, on the other hand, you like well arranged tunes with a solid melodic line and strong percussion, your choice will be Megaman 1 through X (except Megaman 8 and Megaman & Bass).
author: Diego Vizia

text: Wow, I could not disagree more.  I think the music in the Zero games and the ZX games is by far the best the series has ever seen.  But I guess everyone has their own personal tastes....

author: majinon

text:
It's not bad... but MegaMan lost its way gradually.

MegaMan 1 and 2 had great soundtrack. There was a pitfall in MegaMan 3 with only 2 good songs. Megaman 4 soundtrack was great, possibly the best one. MegaMan 5 & 6 were bad. MegaMan 7 Intro was a very good song, but aside from that, only Slashman was good. MegaMan 8 & 9 had no good songs at all. MegaMan X soundtrack was not that bad, but the only really good song is Storm Eagle Stage. And from X2 on, no game had a single good track.
author: Diego Vizia
